title.title: The Correspondence of John Hunt and Joshua Evans

msIdentifier.institution: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

projectDesc.p: The correspondence of Quaker ministers John Hunt and Joshua Evans are stored at the Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College. With the generous support of H. David and Joyce E. Hunt, Library staff scanned and transcribed these letters in 2023 and encoded the text in TEI. The 2023 project also included researching individuals mentioned in the text to create and update records about them in the Social Networks and Archival Context website

div.p: Although I have but little time to spare for letter writing, have felt disposed to send thee a few lines to acknowledge the receipt of thine, about the time of our last Quarterly Meeting in the second month. It was truly acceptable and comforting to receive such a testimonial of thy continued remembrance and regard since. When my mind has been brought into sympathy with thee in thy late close trial; but although the pious life of thy dear daughter in one respect increases the smart of separation, on the other hand it must afford much consolation to believe that she like Mary had chosen that good part that shall never be taken from her, and so was prepared to enter into the joy of her Lord.
It was in my heart to pay thee a visit some weeks back when we came to Moores Town, but the indisposition of our son Joseph prevented that satisfaction.

5th day morning. As thou art prevented by age
and infinity from attaining our annual solemnities. I thought of giving thee a short sketch of our getting along at this time, but being taken with a dizziness in my head and being on a committee that takes up considerable time will necessarily direct me from that purpose, except just in short to say that ancient goodness has been mercifully vouchsafed to qualify friends to profess them far with much harmony and condescension, so that we have had just cause to believe that we as a people shall not be wholly given to reproach, and as encouraged to hope that He who saved us up to be a people, and hath revealed to us that foundation that cannot be shaken, will graciously establish us thereon.

closer.salute: With the salutations of that love which I have from my youth and first acquaintance felt for thee I must conclude thy affectionate friend.
